comments.body: We probably need a couple more tests. Not only tests checking that we reject non-exhaustive pattern matches but also tests that make sure we don't reject anything that is exhaustive. I'm a bit afraid of accidentally rejecting DARs where all pattern matches are exhaustive. This would be particularly bad if people upgrade their DAML engine and afterward can't load packages anymore that were loadable before.
I will add some tests for that.

comments.body:
I think we should add an `ExpTyAbs` test that makes sure we check the kind is well formed, since this is where issues can start to arise. E.g. the expression below contains an ill-formed kind,

```
Î› (Ï„ : â‹† â†’ nat) (Ïƒ: â‹†). Î» (e : Ïƒ) â†’ e
```
The type checker does not fail on such expression, see #7917.

Should definitively go in a separate PR.

comments.body:
Can I recommend splitting this into two test cases? I don't see how the negative ones belong here.

Perhaps "accept well-formed type synonym definitions" and "reject ill-formed type synonym definitions"?

(Wow, "synonym" is hard to type.)

I really like the way this test is written. 

I believe that having in the same unit positive and negative test cases that share most of their code improves the test confidence. Positive test cases check the negative tests are not broken and reciprocally. 

If you untie this relationship by writing two different test cases, you:
1. make the relationship between the two kind of test less obvious.
2. will naturally share less code
3. make easier for developers that will have to refactor this code in the future to break one of the families of tests. 

One compromise would be to use `FreeSpec` instead of `WordSpec` to build a more fine grain hierarchy where both kinds are group together while being separate. However, I do not think this fits the scope of this PR.  

Changing the title of the test does not really help because this makes the notion of negative/positive become blur.
Fair enough, good reasoning. ðŸ™‚
@remyhaemmerle-da Can you please review the changes in this file.
